âœ¨ Key Features: â€¢ Client-side only web application â€¢ Draw ASCII diagrams â€¢ Web-based interface
ðŸ“– Summary: ASCIIFlow is a client-side web application for creating ASCII diagrams directly in the browser. It provides a simple, intuitive interface for drawing and manipulating text-based art without requiring any server-side processing.

âœ¨ hetty | Go
ðŸŽ¯ Primary Use Case: Security research and penetration testing of HTTP applications.
âœ¨ Key Features: â€¢ Machine-in-the-middle (MITM) HTTP proxy with logs and advanced search â€¢ HTTP client for request creation, editing, and replay â€¢ Request and response interception for manual review â€¢ Scope support for organizing work â€¢ Web-based admin interface
ðŸ“– Summary: Hetty is an open-source HTTP toolkit designed for security research, offering a powerful alternative to commercial tools like Burp Suite Pro. It provides a machine-in-the-middle proxy, an HTTP client, and request/response interception capabilities, all managed through an easy-to-use web interface.
ðŸ”— Links: â€¢ View Project â€¢ Homepage ================ ðŸ”“ Open Source

ðŸŒŸ garmin-grafana | Python
ðŸŽ¯ Primary Use Case: To fetch, store, and visualize personal Garmin health data for long-term trend analysis and custom dashboard creation.
âœ¨ Key Features: â€¢ Automatic data collection from Garmin â€¢ Collects comprehensive health metrics (Heart Rate, Steps, Sleep Data, SpO2, HRV, Stress, Body Battery, Calories, Activity Timeline, GPS data) â€¢ Automated data fetching at regular intervals â€¢ Historical data backfilling â€¢ Local data ownership and privacy
ðŸ“– Summary: This repository provides a Dockerized Python script to fetch health data from Garmin Connect and store it in an InfluxDB database. The data can then be visualized using Grafana, allowing users to track long-term health trends and create custom dashboards.
